contextId.information: This question is asked to cause the people of Israel to realize they have disobeyed Yahweh and will suffer because of it. AT: "You have done a terrible thing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is this that you have done?

contextId.information: The women use a question to emphasize that they believe this is what certainly happened.  AT: "They must have so much plunder that it is taking a long time to divide it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have they not found and divided up the plunder?

contextId.information: Gideon uses a question to challenge the stranger's statement that Yahweh was with him. Also, the direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT:  "We have not seen any wonderful deeds like the ones our fathers told us about when Yahweh brought them up from Egypt." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
contextId.quote: Where are all his wonderful deeds that our fathers told us about, when they said, 'Did not Yahweh bring us up from Egypt?'

contextId.information: Yahweh uses a question to ensure Gideon that he is sending him. Here "sent" means Yahweh has appointed Gideon with a specific task. AT: "I, Yahweh, am sending you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have I not sent you?

contextId.information: Gideon uses a question to emphasize that he does not think he can rescue the Israelites. AT: "I cannot possibly rescue the Israelites!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how can I deliver Israel?

contextId.information: Joash uses a question to emphasize that a human should not have to defend a god. AT: "You should not have to defend Baal." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will you plead the case for Baal?

contextId.information: Joash uses a question to emphasize that a human should not have to rescue a god. AT: "You should not have to save Baal." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will you save him?

contextId.information: The people of the tribe of Ephraim were rebuking Gideon with this rhetorical question for not including them in his army. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "You have not treated us fairly." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is this you have done to us?

contextId.information: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. AT: "I have done very little compared with what you have done!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What have I done now compared to you?

contextId.information: Gideon was calming the people of Ephraim with this rhetorical question. AT: "Certainly the grapes you people of Ephraim gleaned are better than what we the descendants of Abiezer gathered from the whole harvest!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]
contextId.quote: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim's grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?

contextId.information: Gideon and his army defeating the Medianites is spoken of as if it were a grape harvest. The people of Ephraim killing Oreb and Zeeb at the end of the battle is spoken of as if they were gleaning grapes at the end of the harvest. AT: "What you people of Ephraim did at the end of the battle is more important than what we descendants of Abiezer did at the beginning." ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Are not the gleanings of Ephraim's grapes better than the full grape harvest of Abiezer?

contextId.information: Gideon uses this question to honor the people of Ephraim. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "What you have done is more important than what I have done." See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What have I accomplished compared to you?

contextId.information: The leaders use a question to emphasize that the Israelites have not yet captured Zebah and Zalumnna. AT: "You have not captured Zebah and Zalmunna yet." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna now in your hand?

contextId.information: The leaders use a question to emphasize that they have no reason to give bread to the Israelites. AT: "We see no reason to give bread to your army." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Why should we give bread to your army?

contextId.information: Gideon quotes the people of Succoth as using a question to mock him. AT: "You have not yet conquered Zebah and Zalmunna." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you already conquered Zebah and Zalmunna?

contextId.information: The vine is asking this question to refuse to be king. This question can be expressed as a statement. AT: "I will not give up my new wine ... over the other trees." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should I give up my new wine ... over the other trees?

contextId.information: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. AT: "We should not serve Abimelech!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him?

contextId.information: Gaal uses a question to emphasize that the people of Shechem should not serve Abimelech. AT: "We should not serve Abimelech!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why should we serve Abimelech?

contextId.information: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with this rhetorical question. The word "their" refers to the Israel. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "therefore, you should not take possession of their land." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: should you now take possession of their land?

contextId.information: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You are not better than Balak son of Zippor, who was king of Moab." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Now are you really better than Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab?

contextId.information: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated with a statement. AT: "Yet he did not dare to have an argument with Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did he dare to have an argument with Israel?

contextId.information: Jephthah is rebuking the king of the Ammonites with a rhetorical question. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "you should have taken them back during that time" or "now it is too late; you should have taken them back long ago." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: why then did you not take them back during that time?

contextId.information: They ask this question to suggest that they could find Samson a wife among their own people. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "Surely there are women among your people whom you could marry." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is there not a woman among the daughters of your relatives, or among all our people?

contextId.information: This question is asked to rebuke Samson. This question can be written as a statement. You can make explicit the reason his parents do not want him to marry a Philistine. AT: "You really should not marry a Philistine woman because the Philistine people do not worship Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Are you going to take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?

contextId.information: They ask her this question to accuse her of inviting them there to make them poor.  This question can be written as a statement. AT: "You have brought us here to make us poor!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did you invite us here in order to make us poor

contextId.information: Samson was rebuking her for demanding that he tell her the answer. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "I have not even told my father or mother. I will not tell you." or "you should not demand that I tell you, since I have not even told my parents, and they are closer to me than you are." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: if I have not told my father or my mother, should I tell you?

contextId.information: The men of Judah ask Samson these questions to rebuke him. This questions may be written as a statements. AT: "You know that the Philistines are rulers over us but you act like they are not. What you have done has caused us great harm." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know that the Philistines are rulers over us? What is this you have done to us?

contextId.information: Delilah asks this question to say that if Samson really loved her he would tell her his secrets. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "When you say 'I love you,' you are lying because you do not share your secrets with me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How can you say, 'I love you,' when you do not share your secrets with me?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question is asked sarcastically and means that they should be doing the opposite. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "You should be acting now!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
contextId.quote: Are you doing nothing?

contextId.information: The five men asked this question to suggest and encourage the men that they should steal the idols. This can be written as a statement, and the implied information may be given in a parenthetical phrase. AT: "these houses contain an ephod, ... metal figure. (They were suggesting that the men steal these things.) Decide ... will do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: in these houses there are an ephod, ... metal figure? Decide ... will do

contextId.information: They ask this as a rhetorical question to imply that it is true. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "It is better for you to be priest for  a tribe and a clan in Israel than for just the house of one man." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it better for you to be priest for the house of one man ... a clan in Israel?

contextId.information: This question is a rebuke. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not have called your men together to chase us." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why have you been called together?

contextId.information: Micah asks this question to emphasize that the Danites definitely know what is bothering him. AT: "You know that I am greatly distressed!'" or "You know how much I am bothered by what you have done to me!'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How can you ask me, 'What is bothering you?'

contextId.information: The people of Israel used this rhetorical question to express their deep sadness. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Oh Yahweh, we are so sad that one of the tribes of Israel has been completely destroyed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why, Yahweh, God of Israel, has this happened to Israel, that one of our tribes should be missing today?
